title: POLITICAL WEEK AHEAD: Zuma leads SA delegation to UN assembly | Politics
text:
United Nations General Assembly begins on Monday and will continue until Saturday. Picture: BLOOMBERG/DANIEL ACKER Related articles Sustainable development goals call for a brave new world World leaders aim high with transformative declaration Anti-corruption march backs Madonsela Solidarity agrees to wage offer but gold producers say deal already off table Gold sector strike looms after unions reject final wage offer In this article Companies and organisations: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa | United Nations People: Riah Phiyega | Nkosinathi Nhleko | Jacob Zuma THE political focus will be in the US this week as President Jacob Zuma leads a state delegation to the 70th session of the United Nations General Assembly.
This comes only weeks after Mr Zumaâ€™s scathing attack on the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (Nato) countries for what he said was their role in instigating the turmoil in Libya and Syria.
The General Assembly is the main deliberative, policy-making and representative organ of the United Nations (UN). Comprising all 193 members, it is a forum for multilateral discussion of the spectrum of international issues covered by the Charter of the UN.
The general debate begins on Monday and will continue until Saturday. The assembly is due to celebrate the 70th anniversary of the establishment of the UN and of the end of the Second World War and the use of nuclear bombs.
Police Minister Nathi Nhleko will on Tuesday release the annual crime statistics against the background of repeated calls for this to be done more than once a year.
Of interest will be whether he will be joined by national police commissioner Riah Phiyega who has until Monday to inform Mr Zuma why she should not be suspended ahead of a board of inquiry into her fitness to hold office.
Gen Phiyega was found to have been dishonest before the Farlam Commission of Inquiry into the shooting deaths of 34 mine workers at Marikana in late 2012.
There will be no action in Parliament this week as the house is in recess until October 12.
However, Parliament and the Union Buildings are expected to be the centre of attention on Wednesday when 300 civil society organisations participate in the Unite Against Corruption march. Organisers say 100,000 people will join the march and that it will be the largest of the democratic era.
While the National Union of Metalworkers of SA (Numsa) has championed the protest, there is doubt whether it will be allowed participate. Numsa had asked the National Economic Development and Labour Council for permission for the strike, but the body only met on Friday and told Numsa the strike certificate would only come into force in two weeks.
The protest, which has elicited support from civil society, faith-based and nongovernmental organisations, was planned for August but has had several delays. The latest was a postponement from September 23 to 30 to avoid conflict with Eid and Yom Kippur.
On Thursday the Council for Conciliation, Mediation and Arbitration resumes its mediation in gold sector wage talks.
